title: Is the sentence 'He's understands now.' grammatically correct? - Quora

response.answer_text: He's understands now. Is grammatically incorrect as in the above sentence , if we carefully watch we will see that the letter (s) is added with the verb understand, but it's grammatically incorrect, we can add( s) or (es) with the verb , when the sentence is present indefinite tense and the subject is third person singular number, Present indefinite tense is written as: Subject + present form of verb + others .and if the subject is third person singular number letter (s) or (es) will be added with the present verb form. So following this rule we can write the above sentence as: He understands now, but the sentence is incorrectly written as: He's understands now. He's is the contracted form of He is , and we can not add (s) or( es) with the present verb form after (be) verb (is), so the sentence : he is understands now, is completely grammtically wrong, the correct form is ; He understands now . It follows the rule of present indefinite tense. Though the above sentence is written grammatically correct yet the sentence does not bear complete sense , If I asks a question to the subject what he understands now ,that is not mentioned in the sentence, so the sentence is written incomplete manner, we can write the sentence like : He understands the real fact now. The above sentence bears a complete sense now.

No that sentence is grammatically incorrect. When you say he’s that is an abbreviation for he is and you can’t say “He is understands now” What you have to say is “He understands now or He is understanding now”.
Absolutely not. the sentence contains two contradictory verbs. “He’s” is a contraction, “He is”, which makes no sense in the meaning of the sentence.
No He understands now is correct. An ‘s is a genitive and would indicate possession, not appropriate here.
No. Expand the contraction and you get, “He is understands now,” which makes no sense.
